Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Molecular Biosciences relies on an understanding of the structure and properties of biological molecules and their interactions. The application of a comparatively small number of underlying chemical principles that govern these properties provides a framework for integration of a large amount of information. This module will build on prior study of chemistry at Level 3 to develop fundamental concepts taken from the traditional areas of organic, inorganic and physical chemistry via the features and properties of biological macromolecules and small molecule metabolites and drugs. Students will become familiar with the foundations of major chemical processes and properties using relevant examples from biological systems and will integrate the central ideas to provide a basis for the study of more complex systems in subsequent modules. Key areas that will be covered include: the thermodynamics of molecular systems and the bioenergetics of living systems; the properties of water and its interactions with biological molecules; the organic structure of biological molecules and their reactions; the mechanisms and kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reactions; practical methods for detecting and observing changes in biological molecules using spectroscopy.

The module will be taught through a combination of self-directed active learning, lectures and workshop sessions, including (further) training in the use of molecular graphics software for the visualisation of molecular structure. Students will initially use a series of carefully chosen representations of biological molecules to collaboratively develop a catalogue of the principles that underpin their properties, which will be elaborated in later sessions, referring back to the initial examples and others to provide context.

The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To support students to develop a working understanding of the chemical principles that underpin the structure and function of biological macromolecules and metabolites.

2. To enable students to apply these principles to a variety of biochemical, biomedical and pharmacological scenarios.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Chemistry for Life Sciences is designed for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3, and builds on prior knowledge to develop an understanding of the chemical principles that underlie the structure and function of macromolecules such as proteins, nucleic acids and polysaccharides, as well as their interactions with small molecule metabolites and drugs. The module is required for students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, and an option for other students with the relevant chemistry background from, for example, Microbiology and Biological Sciences.

The module will begin with an exercise in which students will study a set of representations of macromolecules and small molecules and use their prior knowledge to build a catalogue of the chemical processes relevant to understanding the molecules’ structure and function. These principles (including thermodynamics, kinetics, organic structure and mechanism, acids and bases and basic spectroscopy) will then be developed in later lecture sessions and workshops, which will involve the use of self-assessment questions to test understanding.

The module will be assessed in exam format using technical problems applying the methods addressed, along with interpretation of case studies of biological molecules and their interactions in short answer format.
Outline Syllabus
1. Introduction and self-study of biological molecules.
Outline of structure and properties of a catalogue of biological molecules and their functional groups– a protein, DNA, RNA, polysaccharide, fatty acid, triacyl glycerol, sugar, small metabolites. Properties to include configuration, conformation, charge, hydrophobicity, forces, stability, reactivity, protonation, redox, nucleophilicity, electrophilicity. Drawing molecules – covalent bonds and bond order. Functional groups/naming Acid/Bases Isomers/L-D stereoisomers. Resonance. Key spectroscopic methods to understand these properties such as Absorption, emission fluorescence principles, UV-vis, IR, Basic NMR, Differential Scanning Fluorimetry, dynamic light scattering.

2. The use of molecular graphics software to interact, visualise and illustrate macromolecular structures

3. Biological Thermodynamics - Protein Folding and Other Reactions (how far?)
Systems, First Law, Second Law
Reactions/cells/organisms as thermodynamic systems
Entropy, enthalpy, free energy
Standard Free energy – actual free energy
Equilibrium constant, relationship to standard free energy change.
Drivers of biological processes…
Reduction potential, electron transfer and proton gradients
Understanding energy conversion in biological systems

4. Importance of the aqueous environment in biological systems
H-bonding Polarization
Solvation
H-phobic effect, hydropathy/protein folding, base stacking, membranes
Dissociation, Kw Acids, bases, Ka, pKa Amino acids
Henderson-Hasselbalch and Buffers

5. Enzyme Kinetics and ligand binding (how fast?)
Exponential decline and half-life Radioactivity, drug clearance
Rates of chemical reactions First order, second order Rate constants, rate equations
Relationship to ∆G, equilibria, binding and Kd
Chemical catalysis
Enzyme catalysis ES complex model/steady state Michaelis –Menten
Link to ligand binding
Enzyme inhibition
Competitive, non-competitive, mixed examples.

6. Introduction to Organic Structure and Mechanism
Reactivity as movement of electrons
Examples of key reactions, may include - substitution - carbonyl (acetal/glycosidic bond - Hydrolysis/condensation (peptides/oligos) - Oxidation/Reduction - Catalytic triads
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 2hr workshops.

Active learning: Initial sessions will introduce the scope of the topics covered in the module by way of a series of representations of macromolecules and other biological molecules. Students will use active learning and informal groupwork to develop a map or catalogue of relevant concepts and principles, building on their prior knowledge and based on directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources and searching the literature. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Digital Fluency: Molecular graphics workshops: Alongside these initial sessions, students with develop their skills in interacting, visualising and illustrating macromolecular structure using molecular graphics software (Pymol). This will be used in dedicated workshops as well as in formative short-answer exercises where students will be provided a Pymol session to answer and explore concepts that student groups may screen-share in class.

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics using the catalogue developed above as context and reference, thus explicitly building on students prior learning and initial active learning.

Workshops: Self-assessment questions and problems involving authentic calculations and interpretation of biological situations will be released to students ahead of workshop sessions. The sessions will be used to discuss solutions

Attendance Recorded: yes

Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an online/in person open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination. The case studies will be based on text and/or structures supplied to students for interpretation during the exam time.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
This module is intended for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3 (A level, BTEC, T level, Access to HE, Foundation Course, and similar…) and assumes this background. By definition this includes students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, but other students with Level 3 chemistry may have this module as an option. Students without Level 3 chemistry must discuss their situation before registering for this module.

This new module was developed because of a strategic decision to re-design the teaching of underlying chemical principles to Biochemistry and Pharmacology students. This new approach involves introducing students to key chemical principles starting from familiar biological molecules to provide the relevant context and connections.
Staffing and Expertise: Contribution to teaching will be from BSB, PT, and associated research groups.

In Programmes:Microbiology and Infection BSc (Hons) 2024-25

Chemistry for Life Sciences
Short Title
Chemistry for Life Sciences

Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Molecular Biosciences relies on an understanding of the structure and properties of biological molecules and their interactions. The application of a comparatively small number of underlying chemical principles that govern these properties provides a framework for integration of a large amount of information. This module will build on prior study of chemistry at Level 3 to develop fundamental concepts taken from the traditional areas of organic, inorganic and physical chemistry via the features and properties of biological macromolecules and small molecule metabolites and drugs. Students will become familiar with the foundations of major chemical processes and properties using relevant examples from biological systems and will integrate the central ideas to provide a basis for the study of more complex systems in subsequent modules. Key areas that will be covered include: the thermodynamics of molecular systems and the bioenergetics of living systems; the properties of water and its interactions with biological molecules; the organic structure of biological molecules and their reactions; the mechanisms and kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reactions; practical methods for detecting and observing changes in biological molecules using spectroscopy.

The module will be taught through a combination of self-directed active learning, lectures and workshop sessions, including (further) training in the use of molecular graphics software for the visualisation of molecular structure. Students will initially use a series of carefully chosen representations of biological molecules to collaboratively develop a catalogue of the principles that underpin their properties, which will be elaborated in later sessions, referring back to the initial examples and others to provide context.

The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To support students to develop a working understanding of the chemical principles that underpin the structure and function of biological macromolecules and metabolites.

2. To enable students to apply these principles to a variety of biochemical, biomedical and pharmacological scenarios.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Chemistry for Life Sciences is designed for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3, and builds on prior knowledge to develop an understanding of the chemical principles that underlie the structure and function of macromolecules such as proteins, nucleic acids and polysaccharides, as well as their interactions with small molecule metabolites and drugs. The module is required for students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, and an option for other students with the relevant chemistry background from, for example, Microbiology and Biological Sciences.

The module will begin with an exercise in which students will study a set of representations of macromolecules and small molecules and use their prior knowledge to build a catalogue of the chemical processes relevant to understanding the molecules’ structure and function. These principles (including thermodynamics, kinetics, organic structure and mechanism, acids and bases and basic spectroscopy) will then be developed in later lecture sessions and workshops, which will involve the use of self-assessment questions to test understanding.

The module will be assessed in exam format using technical problems applying the methods addressed, along with interpretation of case studies of biological molecules and their interactions in short answer format.
Outline Syllabus
1. Introduction and self-study of biological molecules.
Outline of structure and properties of a catalogue of biological molecules and their functional groups– a protein, DNA, RNA, polysaccharide, fatty acid, triacyl glycerol, sugar, small metabolites. Properties to include configuration, conformation, charge, hydrophobicity, forces, stability, reactivity, protonation, redox, nucleophilicity, electrophilicity. Drawing molecules – covalent bonds and bond order. Functional groups/naming Acid/Bases Isomers/L-D stereoisomers. Resonance. Key spectroscopic methods to understand these properties such as Absorption, emission fluorescence principles, UV-vis, IR, Basic NMR, Differential Scanning Fluorimetry, dynamic light scattering.

2. The use of molecular graphics software to interact, visualise and illustrate macromolecular structures

3. Biological Thermodynamics - Protein Folding and Other Reactions (how far?)
Systems, First Law, Second Law
Reactions/cells/organisms as thermodynamic systems
Entropy, enthalpy, free energy
Standard Free energy – actual free energy
Equilibrium constant, relationship to standard free energy change.
Drivers of biological processes…
Reduction potential, electron transfer and proton gradients
Understanding energy conversion in biological systems

4. Importance of the aqueous environment in biological systems
H-bonding Polarization
Solvation
H-phobic effect, hydropathy/protein folding, base stacking, membranes
Dissociation, Kw Acids, bases, Ka, pKa Amino acids
Henderson-Hasselbalch and Buffers

5. Enzyme Kinetics and ligand binding (how fast?)
Exponential decline and half-life Radioactivity, drug clearance
Rates of chemical reactions First order, second order Rate constants, rate equations
Relationship to ∆G, equilibria, binding and Kd
Chemical catalysis
Enzyme catalysis ES complex model/steady state Michaelis –Menten
Link to ligand binding
Enzyme inhibition
Competitive, non-competitive, mixed examples.

6. Introduction to Organic Structure and Mechanism
Reactivity as movement of electrons
Examples of key reactions, may include - substitution - carbonyl (acetal/glycosidic bond - Hydrolysis/condensation (peptides/oligos) - Oxidation/Reduction - Catalytic triads
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 2hr workshops.

Active learning: Initial sessions will introduce the scope of the topics covered in the module by way of a series of representations of macromolecules and other biological molecules. Students will use active learning and informal groupwork to develop a map or catalogue of relevant concepts and principles, building on their prior knowledge and based on directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources and searching the literature. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Digital Fluency: Molecular graphics workshops: Alongside these initial sessions, students with develop their skills in interacting, visualising and illustrating macromolecular structure using molecular graphics software (Pymol). This will be used in dedicated workshops as well as in formative short-answer exercises where students will be provided a Pymol session to answer and explore concepts that student groups may screen-share in class.

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics using the catalogue developed above as context and reference, thus explicitly building on students prior learning and initial active learning.

Workshops: Self-assessment questions and problems involving authentic calculations and interpretation of biological situations will be released to students ahead of workshop sessions. The sessions will be used to discuss solutions

Attendance Recorded: yes

Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an online/in person open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination. The case studies will be based on text and/or structures supplied to students for interpretation during the exam time.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
This module is intended for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3 (A level, BTEC, T level, Access to HE, Foundation Course, and similar…) and assumes this background. By definition this includes students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, but other students with Level 3 chemistry may have this module as an option. Students without Level 3 chemistry must discuss their situation before registering for this module.

This new module was developed because of a strategic decision to re-design the teaching of underlying chemical principles to Biochemistry and Pharmacology students. This new approach involves introducing students to key chemical principles starting from familiar biological molecules to provide the relevant context and connections.
Staffing and Expertise: Contribution to teaching will be from BSB, PT, and associated research groups.

Blurb
Overview
Molecular Biosciences relies on an understanding of the structure and properties of biological molecules and their interactions. The application of a comparatively small number of underlying chemical principles that govern these properties provides a framework for integration of a large amount of information. This module will build on prior study of chemistry at Level 3 to develop fundamental concepts taken from the traditional areas of organic, inorganic and physical chemistry via the features and properties of biological macromolecules and small molecule metabolites and drugs. Students will become familiar with the foundations of major chemical processes and properties using relevant examples from biological systems and will integrate the central ideas to provide a basis for the study of more complex systems in subsequent modules. Key areas that will be covered include: the thermodynamics of molecular systems and the bioenergetics of living systems; the properties of water and its interactions with biological molecules; the organic structure of biological molecules and their reactions; the mechanisms and kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reactions; practical methods for detecting and observing changes in biological molecules using spectroscopy.

The module will be taught through a combination of self-directed active learning, lectures and workshop sessions, including (further) training in the use of molecular graphics software for the visualisation of molecular structure. Students will initially use a series of carefully chosen representations of biological molecules to collaboratively develop a catalogue of the principles that underpin their properties, which will be elaborated in later sessions, referring back to the initial examples and others to provide context.

The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To support students to develop a working understanding of the chemical principles that underpin the structure and function of biological macromolecules and metabolites.

2. To enable students to apply these principles to a variety of biochemical, biomedical and pharmacological scenarios.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Chemistry for Life Sciences is designed for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3, and builds on prior knowledge to develop an understanding of the chemical principles that underlie the structure and function of macromolecules such as proteins, nucleic acids and polysaccharides, as well as their interactions with small molecule metabolites and drugs. The module is required for students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, and an option for other students with the relevant chemistry background from, for example, Microbiology and Biological Sciences.

The module will begin with an exercise in which students will study a set of representations of macromolecules and small molecules and use their prior knowledge to build a catalogue of the chemical processes relevant to understanding the molecules’ structure and function. These principles (including thermodynamics, kinetics, organic structure and mechanism, acids and bases and basic spectroscopy) will then be developed in later lecture sessions and workshops, which will involve the use of self-assessment questions to test understanding.

The module will be assessed in exam format using technical problems applying the methods addressed, along with interpretation of case studies of biological molecules and their interactions in short answer format.
Outline Syllabus
1. Introduction and self-study of biological molecules.
Outline of structure and properties of a catalogue of biological molecules and their functional groups– a protein, DNA, RNA, polysaccharide, fatty acid, triacyl glycerol, sugar, small metabolites. Properties to include configuration, conformation, charge, hydrophobicity, forces, stability, reactivity, protonation, redox, nucleophilicity, electrophilicity. Drawing molecules – covalent bonds and bond order. Functional groups/naming Acid/Bases Isomers/L-D stereoisomers. Resonance. Key spectroscopic methods to understand these properties such as Absorption, emission fluorescence principles, UV-vis, IR, Basic NMR, Differential Scanning Fluorimetry, dynamic light scattering.

2. The use of molecular graphics software to interact, visualise and illustrate macromolecular structures

3. Biological Thermodynamics - Protein Folding and Other Reactions (how far?)
Systems, First Law, Second Law
Reactions/cells/organisms as thermodynamic systems
Entropy, enthalpy, free energy
Standard Free energy – actual free energy
Equilibrium constant, relationship to standard free energy change.
Drivers of biological processes…
Reduction potential, electron transfer and proton gradients
Understanding energy conversion in biological systems

4. Importance of the aqueous environment in biological systems
H-bonding Polarization
Solvation
H-phobic effect, hydropathy/protein folding, base stacking, membranes
Dissociation, Kw Acids, bases, Ka, pKa Amino acids
Henderson-Hasselbalch and Buffers

5. Enzyme Kinetics and ligand binding (how fast?)
Exponential decline and half-life Radioactivity, drug clearance
Rates of chemical reactions First order, second order Rate constants, rate equations
Relationship to ∆G, equilibria, binding and Kd
Chemical catalysis
Enzyme catalysis ES complex model/steady state Michaelis –Menten
Link to ligand binding
Enzyme inhibition
Competitive, non-competitive, mixed examples.

6. Introduction to Organic Structure and Mechanism
Reactivity as movement of electrons
Examples of key reactions, may include - substitution - carbonyl (acetal/glycosidic bond - Hydrolysis/condensation (peptides/oligos) - Oxidation/Reduction - Catalytic triads
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 2hr workshops.

Active learning: Initial sessions will introduce the scope of the topics covered in the module by way of a series of representations of macromolecules and other biological molecules. Students will use active learning and informal groupwork to develop a map or catalogue of relevant concepts and principles, building on their prior knowledge and based on directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources and searching the literature. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Digital Fluency: Molecular graphics workshops: Alongside these initial sessions, students with develop their skills in interacting, visualising and illustrating macromolecular structure using molecular graphics software (Pymol). This will be used in dedicated workshops as well as in formative short-answer exercises where students will be provided a Pymol session to answer and explore concepts that student groups may screen-share in class.

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics using the catalogue developed above as context and reference, thus explicitly building on students prior learning and initial active learning.

Workshops: Self-assessment questions and problems involving authentic calculations and interpretation of biological situations will be released to students ahead of workshop sessions. The sessions will be used to discuss solutions

Attendance Recorded: yes

Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. The first (40 %) will consist of short problems (thermodynamics/kinetics/acids/bases) and short-answer questions about the application of these principles and methods to macromolecular structure in an online/in person open book examination.

The second assessment (60 %) will consist of questions relating to the interpretation of one (or two) more extended case-studies of macromolecular interactions, in short answer format in an online/in person open book examination. The case studies will be based on text and/or structures supplied to students for interpretation during the exam time.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
This module is intended for students who have studied chemistry at Level 3 (A level, BTEC, T level, Access to HE, Foundation Course, and similar…) and assumes this background. By definition this includes students studying Biochemistry, Pharmacology and Biomedical Sciences, but other students with Level 3 chemistry may have this module as an option. Students without Level 3 chemistry must discuss their situation before registering for this module.

This new module was developed because of a strategic decision to re-design the teaching of underlying chemical principles to Biochemistry and Pharmacology students. This new approach involves introducing students to key chemical principles starting from familiar biological molecules to provide the relevant context and connections.
Staffing and Expertise: Contribution to teaching will be from BSB, PT, and associated research groups.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To assess and explain the contribution of physical and chemical principles to the structure, properties and reactivity of biological macromolecules and small metabolites.
 LO2 To be proficient in calculations involving basic thermodynamic and kinetic parameters, acids, bases and buffers.
 LO3 To understand the applications of spectroscopy to the analysis of the properties of biological molecules.
